Kekul√© Cells for Molecular Computation

W.H. Hesselink 1, J.C. Hummelen 2, H.T. Jonkman 2,

H.G. Reker 1, G.R. Renardel de Lavalette 1, M.H. van der Veen 2

{w.h.hesselink,j.c.hummelen,harry.jonkman}@rug.nl,
rekerh@cs.man.ac.uk, ¬†g.r.renardel.de.lavalette@rug.nl, marleen.vanderveen@yale.edu
March 16, 2024
1 Computer Science, University of Groningen, The Netherlands
2 Molecular Electronics, Zernike Institute of Advanced Materials,
University of Groningen, The Netherlands

Abstract

The configurations of single and double bonds in polycyclic hydrocarbons are abstracted as Kekul√© states of graphs. Sending a so-called soliton over an open channel between ports (external nodes) of the graph changes the Kekul√© state and therewith the set of open channels in the graph. This switching behaviour is proposed as a basis for molecular computation. The proposal is highly speculative but may have tremendous impact.

Kekul√© states with the same boundary behaviour (port assignment) can be regarded as equivalent. This gives rise to the abstraction of Kekul√© cells. The basic theory of Kekul√© states and Kekul√© cells is developed here, up to the classification of Kekul√© cells with ‚â§4absent4\leq 4 ports. To put the theory in context, we generalize Kekul√© states to semi-Kekul√© states, which form the solutions of a linear system of equations over the field of the bits 0 and 1. We briefly study so-called omniconjugated graphs, in which every port assignment of the right signature has a Kekul√© state. Omniconjugated graphs may be useful as connectors between computational elements. We finally investigate some examples with potentially useful switching behaviour.

1 Introduction

In the quest for smaller and smaller computational elements, we may hope to arrive one day at the level of molecules. Controllable electrical conductance within molecules is the realm of chemistry. One proposal in this direction is to use so-called œÄùúã\pi-conjugation in polycyclic hydrocarbons, as studied in Marleen van der Veen‚Äôs PhD thesis ‚ÄúœÄùúã\pi-Logic‚Äù [17].

The development of this field of œÄùúã\pi-conjugation and œÄùúã\pi-logic needs several abstractions that belong to branches of mathematics like graph theory and linear algebra. In mathematics, the symbol œÄùúã\pi is primarily associated with the circumference and the area of the circle. The term ‚Äúconjugation‚Äù has also several connotations in mathematics. In this paper, conjugation means the constructive interaction between a pair of neighbouring (carbon-carbon) œÄùúã\pi-orbitals, leading to delocalisation of the electrons.

The basic physical idea is that the configuration of single and double bonds in certain polycyclic ‚Äòaromatic‚Äô [note: these are polyunsaturated hydrocarbons, usually referred to as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), but they need not be aromatic in the strict chemical sense] hydrocarbons influences the electrical conductivity between points of the molecule, and can be influenced by electrical signals over channels in the molecule. In other words, the molecule can serve as a switch. Since it was Kekul√© who proposed, in 1865, the alternating single and double bonds in the benzene ring (one of the simplest cyclic hydrocarbons), we prefer to associate the basic ideas to be exposed here with the name Kekul√©.

The polycyclic hydrocarbons we are considering have boundary atoms that can serve as ports to probe and modify the electronic properties of the molecules. The electrical resistance between two ports is low when there is a path of alternating single and double bonds between them [20]. By sending a so-called soliton over the alternating path, the single and double bonds along the path are toggled [6]. Such toggling of an alternating path may open or close other alternating paths in the molecule. This is the switching behaviour alluded to. The toggling can also be done by chemical means (for example a redox reaction [1, 19]).

In our abstraction of the molecule, the graph of the atoms and bonds is kept fixed, while it is allowed to change the multiplicities (single or double) of the bonds. A configuration of bonds such that every internal node has precisely one double bond is called a Kekul√© state. Nodes with precisely one edge to the remainder of the graph are called ports. The port assignment of a Kekul√© state describes the multiplicities of the bonds at the ports. A pair of ports is called a channel. A channel is called open (low resistance) in a Kekul√© state if there is an alternating path between its ports.

Another reason for naming the configurations Kekul√© states is that they are to represent closed shell molecules (‚ÄòKekul√© structures‚Äô), i.e., molecules in which all electrons are paired, as opposed to non-Kekul√© states.

The term ‚ÄòKekul√© state‚Äô has its chemical equivalent in ‚Äòresonance structure‚Äô (or ‚Äòresonance contributor‚Äô), with the restriction of being a system that is closed-shell and without charges. The number of different Kekul√© states of the graph is a measure of the stability of the molecule. In this sense, Kekul√© states represent all structures that are regarded in the Valence Bond Theory [8, 7, 2, 15] of molecules (as opposed to Molecular Orbital Theory, that also includes charged and open shell configurations as parts for the total quantum mechanical description of the electronic structure of a molecule).

The Kekul√© state is a debatable abstraction. The actual quantum-mechanical state is a weighted superposition of many states, in which the Kekul√© states have high weights; e.g., the two Kekul√© states of the benzene hexagon are just two components of a single quantum-mechanical state. This does not matter for the switching behaviour described, however, because it turns out that all Kekul√© states with the same port assignment have the same open (closed) channels between ports, see Theorem 2.2 in section 2.2. It follows that the effect of sending a soliton over an open channel only effects the port assignment, and consists of toggling the port assignment only at the ports of the channel.

We introduce Kekul√© cells to capture this behaviour. More precisely, we introduce a mathematical concept cell that captures the behaviour, and Kekul√© cells are those that can be obtained from graphs with single and double bonds in them.

A serious physical objection is that the Kekul√© states form a qualitative characteristic of the state, whereas the precise energy levels of the various eigen-states are quantitative. This objection must be dealt with when the qualitative investigations are leading to actual technical proposals.

Van der Veen et al.¬†[18] have first proposed certain œÄùúã\pi-conjugated systems that can act as ‚Äòsoldering points‚Äô for molecular wires in the sense that linear œÄùúã\pi-conjugated pathways between all ports (‚Äòterminals‚Äô) exist; i.e., ‚Äòomniconjugated‚Äô systems. Subsequently, œÄùúã\pi-logic [17] was proposed as a way to perform any Boolean operation within certain œÄùúã\pi-conjugated hydrocarbon frameworks, bearing a number of ports. We now formalize this approach in a rigorous mathematical and topological way.

The application of graph theory to chemistry is not new. One of the research areas is the search for quantitative structure-property relationships based on molecular connectivity invariants of the hydrogen-suppressed chemical graphs, see the overview article [13]. The invariants are numerical functions of graphs that can be related to properties of classes of compounds like, e.g., solubility, crystal density, melting point, etc. In [16], it is proposed that one of these invariants (a generalized Randic index) for a certain class of hydrocarbons can be interpreted as an energy functional that depends on the œÄùúã\pi-electron density. The paper [4] goes beyond numerical invariants and studies energy levels of œÄùúã\pi-conjugated systems by means of the symmetry groups of the graphs. In our application of graph theory, numerical invariants and the symmetry of the graphs play no roles yet.

1.1 Overview

The formalization steps we need are first sketched in section 1.2. In section 1.3, we present the mathematical notations that we need. The graph theory needed is presented in section 1.4.

In section 2, we present the theory of Kekul√© states and Kekul√© cells, up to the classification of Kekul√© cells with four ports. Section 3 contains the theory of semi-Kekul√© states. Here it is proved that the number of Kekul√© states for a given port assignment is ‚â§2e+1‚àívabsentsuperscript2ùëí1ùë£\leq 2^{e+1-v} where eùëíe is the number of edges and vùë£v is the number of nodes of the graph. This section serves as an aside to provide context for the Kekul√© states, but is not really needed for the application. In section 4, we discuss graphs for which the Kekul√© cell is as large as possible; such graphs are said to be omniconjugated. In section 5, we investigate the functionality of cells for switching behaviour. Conclusions are drawn in section 6.

1.2 The formalization steps

We now briefly sketch the central concepts of the theory. Precise definitions are postponed.

It is natural and conventional to represent molecules by graphs with the nodes for atoms and the edges for bonds. Polycyclic polyunsaturated hydrocarbons are usually almost flat, so that their graphs are planar. We use a subgraph to indicate the set of double bonds of a given molecule.

Nodes of the graph that are linked via only one edge to the remainder of the graph are called ports. A port assignment is a set of ports used to indicate the ports that are to be attached by a double bond. The Kekul√© cell associated to a graph with port set PùëÉP is the set of port assignments in PùëÉP that allow Kekul√© states.

A cell in PùëÉP is defined to be an arbitrary set of port assignments in PùëÉP. A cell is a Kekul√© cell if there is some graph for which the cell is the set of Kekul√© port assignments. A functional cell is a cell together with an initial port assignment and a system of channels to probe and modify the current port assignment.

1.3 Mathematical concepts and notations

In this paper, a number of mathematical theorems (and lemmas and corollaries) are proved. The end of such a proof is indicated by the symbol ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box. The Theorems 1, 2, and 3 and Corollary 1 have been verified with the mechanical theorem prover PVS [12] as a student project (the report and the proof scripts are available on request). The symbol ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box¬†is also used at the end of the examples and remarks.

If SùëÜS is a set, we write x‚ààSùë•ùëÜx\in S to denote that xùë•x is an element of SùëÜS. We write #‚ÄãS#ùëÜ\#S to denote the number of elements of SùëÜS.

If SùëÜS and TùëáT are sets, we write S‚à™TùëÜùëáS\cup T for the union of SùëÜS and TùëáT, which is the set of the elements xùë•x with x‚ààSùë•ùëÜx\in S or x‚ààTùë•ùëáx\in T (or both). The intersection S‚à©TùëÜùëáS\cap T consists of the elements xùë•x with x‚ààSùë•ùëÜx\in S and x‚ààTùë•ùëáx\in T. We write S‚àñTùëÜùëáS\setminus T for the difference of SùëÜS and TùëáT, i.e., the set of elements of SùëÜS that are not in TùëáT.

A set SùëÜS is called a subset of a set UùëàU (notation S‚äÜUùëÜùëàS\subseteq U) if every element of SùëÜS is an element of UùëàU. The power set Pow‚Äã(U)Powùëà\mbox{{Pow}}(U) of UùëàU is defined as the set of subsets of UùëàU.

We write S‚äïTdirect-sumùëÜùëáS\oplus T for the symmetric difference, which is S‚äïT=(S‚àñT)‚à™(T‚àñS)direct-sumùëÜùëáùëÜùëáùëáùëÜS\oplus T=(S\setminus T)\cup(T\setminus S). It is easy to verify that ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus is commutative: S‚äïT=T‚äïSdirect-sumùëÜùëádirect-sumùëáùëÜS\oplus T=T\oplus S and associative: (S‚äïT)‚äïR=S‚äï(T‚äïR)direct-sumdirect-sumùëÜùëáùëÖdirect-sumùëÜdirect-sumùëáùëÖ(S\oplus T)\oplus R=S\oplus(T\oplus R), and that the empty set ‚àÖ\emptyset satisfies ‚àÖ‚äïS=Sdirect-sumùëÜùëÜ\emptyset\oplus S=S and S‚äïS=‚àÖdirect-sumùëÜùëÜS\oplus S=\emptyset. Therefore, Pow‚Äã(U)Powùëà\mbox{{Pow}}(U) with operation ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus is a commutative group with neutral element ‚àÖ\emptyset.

1.4 Undirected graphs

There is no standard terminology in graph theory, cf.¬†[5]. In this note, all graphs are finite, undirected graphs without isolated nodes, multiple edges, or self-loops.

We formalize our graphs in the following way. The basic constituents of graphs are nodes (vertices). An edge is defined to be a set that consists of two distinct nodes. A graph is defined to be a finite set of edges. The nodes of a graph are the elements of its edges. If Gùê∫G is a graph, we write n‚ÄãGùëõùê∫nG for its set of nodes. The ports of graph Gùê∫G are the nodes that occur in precisely one edge of Gùê∫G (ports are called sites or terminals in [17]). We write p‚ÄãGùëùùê∫pG to denote the set of ports of graph Gùê∫G. A node of Gùê∫G is called internal if it is not a port. We write i‚ÄãGùëñùê∫iG to denote the set of internal nodes of Gùê∫G. So we have i‚ÄãG=n‚ÄãG‚àñp‚ÄãGùëñùê∫ùëõùê∫ùëùùê∫iG=nG\setminus pG.

The degree of a node vùë£v of graph Gùê∫G is the number of edges of Gùê∫G that contain vùë£v. Therefore, a node of Gùê∫G is a port if and only if its degree is 1. In view of the application to conjugation in carbon chemistry, we could restrict attention to graphs where all nodes have degrees ‚â§4absent4\leq 4. Since we have no use for this restriction, we do this only in some examples.

We often represent graphs by drawing the nodes as bullets and the edges as line segments between the nodes. The graph drawn here has two ports and three internal nodes, one of degree 2 and two of degree 3.

Two distinct nodes pùëùp and qùëûq are defined to be connected in graph Gùê∫G if there is a sequence of nodes (p0,‚Ä¶,pn)subscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëùùëõ(p_{0},\dots,p_{n}) with p0=psubscriptùëù0ùëùp_{0}=p and pn=qsubscriptùëùùëõùëûp_{n}=q and (pi,pi+1)‚ààGsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùê∫(p_{i},p_{i+1})\in G for all 0‚â§i<n0ùëñùëõ0\leq i<n. Graph Gùê∫G is called connected if it is nonempty and every pair of distinct nodes of Gùê∫G is connected in Gùê∫G. Graph Gùê∫G is called a simple path between nodes pùëùp and qùëûq if it is connected, pùëùp and qùëûq are its only ports, and all its other nodes have degree 2. Graph Gùê∫G is called a cycle if it is connected and all its nodes have degree 2.

Since a graph is just a set of edges, every subset of a graph Gùê∫G is itself a graph, and can therefore be called a subgraph. A subgraph Cùê∂C of Gùê∫G is called a curve in Gùê∫G if every node of Cùê∂C which is internal in Gùê∫G has degree 2 in Cùê∂C.

The empty subgraph is a curve. More interesting examples of curves are cycles, and simple paths between ports. Conversely, every connected component of a curve is a cycle or a simple path between ports.

2 Kekul√© States

The concept of Kekul√© states is motivated by their correspondence to œÄùúã\pi-conjugated systems in chemistry. Polycyclic polyunsaturated hydrocarbons are molecules in which carbon atoms are organized in rings, mainly hexagons, but possibly also pentagons and heptagons. The primary example would be naphthalene, consisting of two fused benzene rings.

In 1865, August Kekul√© proposed that a benzene molecule should consist of a hexagon of carbon atoms with attached hydrogen in an alternating cycle of double bonds and single bonds. In our graph theoretical abstraction, we neglect all hydrogen atoms. All carbon atoms are represented by nodes of the graph, all bonds are represented by edges. So, they are the hydrogen suppressed chemical graphs of [13].

We represent the set of double bonds by a subgraph of the graph of the molecule. In common polycyclic polyunsaturated hydrocarbons, the rule is that every carbon atom is sp2 hybridized and has precisely one double bond. The ports represent other atoms that are linked to the graph by single or double bonds. This leads to the following definition.

We define a Kekul√© state WùëäW in graph Gùê∫G to be a subgraph of Gùê∫G such that every internal node of Gùê∫G is a port of WùëäW.

In graph theory, a subgraph WùëäW of Gùê∫G is called a perfect matching if every node of Gùê∫G is a port of WùëäW [5, p.¬†203]. It follows that WùëäW is a perfect matching if and only if WùëäW is a Kekul√© state and WùëäW contains all edges to ports.

Example 1

The graph shown in section 1.4 has no perfect matchings, and has two Kekul√© states, one of which ({e,f}ùëíùëì\{e,f\}) is shown below by doubling its edges eùëíe and fùëìf. If we give the bottom node an additional edge to a new port, the resulting graph has one perfect matching and four Kekul√© states.

Efficient algorithms exist to determine whether a given graph has a perfect matching [10]. These algorithms can easily be adapted to yield Kekul√© states. In the remainder of this paper, we have no need to consider perfect matchings.

Remark 1

There are graphs, even with several ports, that have no Kekul√© states. The lefthand graph below is an example, as is easily verified. In this graph, the lower part with the two ports can be replaced by any other subgraph with any number of ports.

The righthand graph in the figure is a case with precisely one Kekul√© state, even though the graph has two ports. In either case, the triangles can be replaced by pentagons to better meet the possibilities of carbon chemistry.

The chemical equivalents of the two structures are depicted below. The structure at the left is an open shell (non-Kekul√©) radical structure with the bullet at a Kekul√© violation. The structure at the right is a closed shell (Kekul√©) structure.

2.1 Alternating curves

The electronic properties of Kekul√© states are observed at and controlled by alternating paths, or more generally alternating curves.

An alternating curve is a pair (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) of subgraphs of Gùê∫G such that Cùê∂C is a curve in Gùê∫G and that the intersection W‚à©Cùëäùê∂W\cap C is a Kekul√© state of Cùê∂C. Since all internal nodes of Cùê∂C have degree 2, this means that every internal node of Cùê∂C belongs to one edge of WùëäW and one edge of C‚àñWùê∂ùëäC\setminus W, whence the name ‚Äúalternating‚Äù.

Roughly speaking, the next result says that the difference between any two Kekul√© states is an alternating curve, and that, if at least one Kekul√© state exists, every alternating curve is obtained in this way.

Theorem 2.1

(a) Let WùëäW and W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} be Kekul√© states of a graph Gùê∫G. Then the subgraph C=W‚äïW‚Ä≤ùê∂direct-sumùëäsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤C=W\oplus W^{\prime} is a curve in Gùê∫G and (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) is an alternating curve.
(b) Let WùëäW be a Kekul√© state of graph Gùê∫G and let (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) be an alternating curve in Gùê∫G. Then W‚Ä≤=W‚äïCsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤direct-sumùëäùê∂W^{\prime}=W\oplus C is a Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G.

Proof

(a) Let vùë£v be a node of Cùê∂C which is an internal node of Gùê∫G. Since WùëäW and W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} are Kekul√© states of Gùê∫G, each contains precisely one edge, say e‚ààWùëíùëäe\in W and e‚Ä≤‚ààW‚Ä≤superscriptùëí‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤e^{\prime}\in W^{\prime}, that contains vùë£v. Since vùë£v is a node of C=W‚äïW‚Ä≤ùê∂direct-sumùëäsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤C=W\oplus W^{\prime}, these edges are different. Therefore, both belong to Cùê∂C. It also follows that Cùê∂C has no other edges that contain vùë£v. Therefore vùë£v has degree 2 in Cùê∂C. This proves that Cùê∂C is a curve in Gùê∫G. Moreover, since we have e‚ààW‚àñW‚Ä≤ùëíùëäsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤e\in W\setminus W^{\prime} and e‚Ä≤‚ààW‚Ä≤‚àñWsuperscriptùëí‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùëäe^{\prime}\in W^{\prime}\setminus W, the pair (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) is alternating.

(b) In order to show that W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} is a Kekul√© state, we need to show that every internal node vùë£v of Gùê∫G is a port of W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime}. Since WùëäW is a Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G, there is a unique edge e‚ààWùëíùëäe\in W with v‚ààeùë£ùëív\in e. If vùë£v is not a node of Cùê∂C, then eùëíe is also the unique edge of W‚äïCdirect-sumùëäùê∂W\oplus C that contains vùë£v. Assume therefore that vùë£v is a node of Cùê∂C. Since Cùê∂C is a curve, vùë£v is internal in Cùê∂C and has degree 2 in Cùê∂C. Since (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) is an alternating curve, it follows that there is a unique edge e‚ààW‚à©Cùëíùëäùê∂e\in W\cap C and a unique edge e‚Ä≤‚ààC‚àñWsuperscriptùëí‚Ä≤ùê∂ùëäe^{\prime}\in C\setminus W with v‚ààeùë£ùëív\in e and v‚ààe‚Ä≤ùë£superscriptùëí‚Ä≤v\in e^{\prime}. It follows that e‚Ä≤superscriptùëí‚Ä≤e^{\prime} is the unique edge of W‚äïC=W‚Ä≤direct-sumùëäùê∂superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W\oplus C=W^{\prime} that contains vùë£v. Therefore vùë£v is a port of W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime}. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

2.2 Port assignments

We now want to prescribe the port behaviour of Kekul√© states. Let Gùê∫G be a graph with a set of ports PùëÉP. We define a port assignment (‚Äúarchetype‚Äù in [17]) to be a subset of PùëÉP. For any subgraph WùëäW of Gùê∫G, we define W|PconditionalùëäùëÉW|P as the set of nodes of WùëäW that also belong to PùëÉP, i.e.,¬†(W|P)=P‚à©n‚ÄãWconditionalùëäùëÉùëÉùëõùëä(W|P)=P\cap nW. A port assignment gùëîg is called Kekul√© if there is a Kekul√© state WùëäW of Gùê∫G with g=(W|P)ùëîconditionalùëäùëÉg=(W|P).

In chemistry, the different Kekul√© states with the same port assignment are called resonance structures. The actual quantum mechanical state is a superposition of these resonance structures. In the Valence Bond Theory picture, the actual quantum mechanical state is taken as a weighted superposition of these (neutral) resonance structures. The number of neutral closed shell resonance structures is determined by the number of alternating curves in the following way:

Corollary 1

Let Gùê∫G be a graph with p‚ÄãG=Pùëùùê∫ùëÉpG=P. Let gùëîg be a port assignment in PùëÉP. Let nùëõn be the number of Kekul√© states WùëäW of Gùê∫G with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g. For every Kekul√© state WùëäW with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g, there are precisely nùëõn curves Cùê∂C without ports such that (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) is alternating (including the empty curve).

Proof

This follows from Theorem 2.1 by the observation that WùëäW and W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} give the same port assignments if and only if the curve W‚äïW‚Ä≤direct-sumùëäsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤W\oplus W^{\prime} has no ports. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Example 2

Phenantrene consists of three hexagons without any ports. One of its Kekul√© states is depicted here.

This Kekul√© state has five alternating curves. Four of them are easy to find: the empty curve, two cycles of length 6 around the extreme hexagons, and one cycle of length 10 around the two horizontal neighbouring hexagons. The remaining alternating curve is disconnected: it is the union of the two cycles of length 6. Phenantrene has therefore five Kekul√© states. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

In chemistry, i.e., within Valence Bond Theory, the number of Kekul√© states of a port assignment is an indication of its stability. Here the Kekul√© structures having the highest number of aromatic rings (rings with 4‚Äãn+24ùëõ24n+2 electrons; usually 6, as in benzene) are considered as the most important resonance contributors.

We now come to the central result of this paper that says that the existence of an alternating path between two given ports is completely determined by the set of Kekul√© port assignments. It follows that the switching behavour of the graph is also completely determined by the set of Kekul√© port assignments and hence independent of all other aspects of the graph.

In order to formulate this result, we note that, for distinct ports pùëùp and qùëûq, the doubleton set {p,q}ùëùùëû\{p,q\} is a port assignment.

Theorem 2.2

Let port assignment kùëòk satisfy k=(W|P)ùëòconditionalùëäùëÉk=(W|P) for some Kekul√© state WùëäW. Let pùëùp and qùëûq be distinct ports. There is a simple alternating path (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) from pùëùp to qùëûq in Gùê∫G if and only if the port assignment k‚äï{p,q}direct-sumùëòùëùùëûk\oplus\{p,q\} is Kekul√©.

Proof

If there is a simple alternating path (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) from pùëùp to qùëûq in Gùê∫G, Theorem 2.1(b) implies that W‚Ä≤=W‚äïCsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤direct-sumùëäùê∂W^{\prime}=W\oplus C is a Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G. It satisfies (W‚Ä≤|P)=k‚äï{p,q}conditionalsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùëÉdirect-sumùëòùëùùëû(W^{\prime}|P)=k\oplus\{p,q\}.

Conversely, if the port assignment k‚äï{p,q}direct-sumùëòùëùùëûk\oplus\{p,q\} is Kekul√©, let W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} be a Kekul√© state with (W‚Ä≤|P)=k‚äï{p,q}conditionalsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùëÉdirect-sumùëòùëùùëû(W^{\prime}|P)=k\oplus\{p,q\} and let C‚Ä≤=W‚äïW‚Ä≤superscriptùê∂‚Ä≤direct-sumùëäsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤C^{\prime}=W\oplus W^{\prime}. Then (C‚Ä≤,W)superscriptùê∂‚Ä≤ùëä(C^{\prime},W) is an alternating curve by Theorem 2.1(a). The Kekul√© states WùëäW and W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} agree on all ports except for pùëùp and qùëûq. Therefore, the graph C‚Ä≤superscriptùê∂‚Ä≤C^{\prime} only contains the ports pùëùp and qùëûq. Let Cùê∂C be the connected component of pùëùp in C‚Ä≤superscriptùê∂‚Ä≤C^{\prime}. Then it also contains qùëûq and (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) is a simple alternating path from pùëùp to qùëûq in Gùê∫G. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Theorem 2.2 implies that all Kekul√© states corresponding to a given Kekul√© port assignment agree on the question which ports are connected by alternating paths, and that the result is determined completely by the set of Kekul√© port assignments.

The physical relevance of Theorem 2.2 is that an alternating path between a pair of ports is, electrically, an open channel (low resistance), and that the channel is closed in the absence of alternating paths [11, 9, 3]. This leads to the following formal definitions.

In view of Theorem 2.2, we define a channel to be a port assignment of the form {p,q}ùëùùëû\{p,q\} for distinct ports pùëùp and qùëûq. A channel cùëêc is defined to be open with respect to a set KùêæK of port assignments and an element k‚ààKùëòùêæk\in K if and only if k‚äïc‚ààKdirect-sumùëòùëêùêæk\oplus c\in K.

The idea is that KùêæK stands for the set of Kekul√© port assignments of some graph. If a channel cùëêc is open for k‚ààKùëòùêæk\in K, one can send a so-called soliton through the channel with the effect that state kùëòk is replaced by k‚äïcdirect-sumùëòùëêk\oplus c [17]. Indeed, the element k‚ààKùëòùêæk\in K is regarded as a memory state. It is up to the physics to determine how long such memory states can be preserved.

Example 3

One of the simplest cases is an ethene molecule with three attached ports p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}, p1subscriptùëù1p_{1}, p2subscriptùëù2p_{2}. The initial port assignment is ‚àÖ\emptyset. We use the channels A={p0,p1}ùê¥subscriptùëù0subscriptùëù1A=\{p_{0},p_{1}\} and T={p0,p2}ùëásubscriptùëù0subscriptùëù2T=\{p_{0},p_{2}\}. There are three Kekul√© states, as depicted below. The corresponding port assignments are ‚àÖ\emptyset, Aùê¥A and A‚äïT={p1,p2}direct-sumùê¥ùëásubscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2A\oplus T=\{p_{1},p_{2}\}. Port assignment TùëáT is non-Kekul√©.

Initially, channel Aùê¥A is open and TùëáT is closed. When Aùê¥A is signalled, we arrive at the middle state: this opens TùëáT, while Aùê¥A remains open. If Aùê¥A is signalled again, we return to the initial state where TùëáT is closed. We may use the system as a simple switch to open and close TùëáT by means of Aùê¥A. Note, however, that if Aùê¥A opens TùëáT, and TùëáT is then read, i.e., is signalled, we arrive at the righthand state where channel Aùê¥A is closed. Therefore, in order to preserve the system as a switch, reading this memory cell must be done by signalling the channel twice. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

2.3 Abstraction from the graphs

At this point we take the abstraction step to concentrate on the ports and the port assignments and treat the specific graph itself merely as auxiliary. From here on, PùëÉP is an arbitrary finite set and the elements of PùëÉP are called ports. The subsets of PùëÉP are called port assignments. Just as before, a channel is a port assignment of the form {p,q}ùëùùëû\{p,q\} for distinct ports pùëùp and qùëûq.

Recall from section 1.3 that the set Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) of the port assignments is a commutative group with operation ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus. We define Even‚Äã(P)EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Even}}(P) and Odd‚Äã(P)OddùëÉ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) to be the subsets of Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) that consist of the port asignments with an even (odd) number of ports. It is easy to verify that Even‚Äã(P)EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Even}}(P) is a subgroup of Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) and that Odd‚Äã(P)OddùëÉ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) is not.

For #‚ÄãP=4#ùëÉ4\#P=4, the sets Even‚Äã(P)EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Even}}(P) and Odd‚Äã(P)OddùëÉ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) are depicted in Figure 5.5 of [17]. Table 5.10 of [17] gives the table of the operation ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus in Even‚Äã(P)EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Even}}(P). The group Even‚Äã(P)EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Even}}(P) acts on Odd‚Äã(P)OddùëÉ\mbox{{Odd}}(P) in the sense that g‚äïh‚ààOdd‚Äã(P)direct-sumùëî‚ÑéOddùëÉg\oplus h\in\mbox{{Odd}}(P) for all g‚ààEven‚Äã(P)ùëîEvenùëÉg\in\mbox{{Even}}(P) and h‚ààOdd‚Äã(P)‚ÑéOddùëÉh\in\mbox{{Odd}}(P). All channels are elements of Even‚Äã(P)EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Even}}(P).

For any two port assignments kùëòk, k‚Ä≤‚ààPow‚Äã(P)superscriptùëò‚Ä≤PowùëÉk^{\prime}\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P), we define the Hamming distance dist‚Äã(k,k‚Ä≤)distùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤\mbox{{dist}}(k,k^{\prime}) as the number of ports in k‚äïk‚Ä≤direct-sumùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤k\oplus k^{\prime}. It is easy to verify that dist‚Äã(k,k‚Ä≤)distùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤\mbox{{dist}}(k,k^{\prime}) is always ‚â•0absent0\geq 0, and that it is zero if and only if k=k‚Ä≤ùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤k=k^{\prime}. Recall that, in any group, translation is the operation that adds a fixed element to its argument. The Hamming distance is translation invariant: dist‚Äã(g‚äïk,g‚äïk‚Ä≤)=dist‚Äã(k,k‚Ä≤)distdirect-sumùëîùëòdirect-sumùëîsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤distùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤\mbox{{dist}}(g\oplus k,g\oplus k^{\prime})=\mbox{{dist}}(k,k^{\prime}) for all gùëîg, kùëòk, k‚Ä≤‚ààPow‚Äã(P)superscriptùëò‚Ä≤PowùëÉk^{\prime}\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P).

2.4 Cells and Kekul√© cells

A cell over PùëÉP is defined to be a subset of Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P). A channel cùëêc is defined to be open with respect to a cell KùêæK and a state k‚ààKùëòùêæk\in K, if and only if k‚äïc‚ààKdirect-sumùëòùëêùêæk\oplus c\in K. In accordance with Theorem 2.2, the interpretation is that a signal can be sent over channel cùëêc if and only if the channel is open and that, in that case, the state is transformed into k‚äïcdirect-sumùëòùëêk\oplus c.

For any graph Gùê∫G, we let KP‚Äã(G)KPùê∫\mbox{{KP}}(G) denote the set of the Kekul√© port assignments of Gùê∫G. Clearly KP‚Äã(G)KPùê∫\mbox{{KP}}(G) is a cell over PùëÉP, i.e., a subset of Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P). An arbitrary cell KùêæK over PùëÉP is called a Kekul√© cell if and only if there is a graph Gùê∫G with P=p‚ÄãGùëÉùëùùê∫P=pG and K=KP‚Äã(G)ùêæKPùê∫K=\mbox{{KP}}(G).

At this point the question is: how arbitrary are Kekul√© cells? Our first result in this direction is that Kekul√© cells are preserved by translation. If KùêæK is a cell and gùëîg is a port assignment, the translated cell g‚äïKdirect-sumùëîùêæg\oplus K is defined by g‚äïK={g‚äïk‚à£k‚ààK}direct-sumùëîùêæconditional-setdirect-sumùëîùëòùëòùêæg\oplus K=\{g\oplus k\mid k\in K\}.

Theorem 2.3

Let KùêæK be a Kekul√© cell over PùëÉP. Let g‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ùëîPowùëÉg\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P). Then g‚äïKdirect-sumùëîùêæg\oplus K is also a Kekul√© cell over PùëÉP.

Proof

Choose a graph Gùê∫G with P=p‚ÄãGùëÉùëùùê∫P=pG and K=KP‚Äã(G)ùêæKPùê∫K=\mbox{{KP}}(G). It suffices to construct a graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} with g‚äïK=KP‚Äã(G‚Ä≤)direct-sumùëîùêæKPsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤g\oplus K=\mbox{{KP}}(G^{\prime}). We construct G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} from Gùê∫G. For every port p‚ààgùëùùëîp\in g, we replace the (unique) edge of Gùê∫G that contains pùëùp by two edges linked by a new internal node. More precisely, let each edge e={p,v}ùëíùëùùë£e=\{p,v\} with p‚ààgùëùùëîp\in g be replaced by the edges {p,v‚Ä≤}ùëùsuperscriptùë£‚Ä≤\{p,v^{\prime}\} and {v‚Ä≤,v}superscriptùë£‚Ä≤ùë£\{v^{\prime},v\}. If WùëäW is a Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G, let W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} be the subgraph of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} that consists of W‚à©G‚Ä≤ùëäsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤W\cap G^{\prime} together with all edges {v‚Ä≤,v}superscriptùë£‚Ä≤ùë£\{v^{\prime},v\} with p‚ààgùëùùëîp\in g and {p,v}‚ààWùëùùë£ùëä\{p,v\}\in W, and all edges {p,v‚Ä≤}ùëùsuperscriptùë£‚Ä≤\{p,v^{\prime}\} with p‚ààgùëùùëîp\in g and {p,v}‚ààG‚àñWùëùùë£ùê∫ùëä\{p,v\}\in G\setminus W. Then W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} is a Kekul√© state of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} with W‚Ä≤|P=g‚äï(W|P)conditionalsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùëÉdirect-sumùëîconditionalùëäùëÉW^{\prime}|P=g\oplus(W|P). Moreover, every Kekul√© state W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is obtained in this way. This shows that g‚äïK=KP‚Äã(G‚Ä≤)direct-sumùëîùêæKPsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤g\oplus K=\mbox{{KP}}(G^{\prime}). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

We now prove a result that shows that every Kekul√© cell is ‚Äúconnected by channels‚Äù in a certain, rather strong, sense. For any set Dùê∑D of port assignments we use the notation ‚®ÅDdirect-sumùê∑\bigoplus D to denote the ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus sum of the elements of Dùê∑D.

Theorem 2.4

Let KùêæK be a Kekul√© cell over PùëÉP. For every pair of elements gùëîg, g‚Ä≤‚ààKsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùêæg^{\prime}\in K, the Hamming distance dist‚Äã(g,g‚Ä≤)distùëîsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤\mbox{{dist}}(g,g^{\prime}) is even and there is a set Dùê∑D of disjoint channels such that g‚Ä≤=g‚äï(‚®ÅD)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤direct-sumùëîdirect-sumùê∑g^{\prime}=g\oplus(\bigoplus D) and dist‚Äã(g,g‚Ä≤)=2‚ãÖ#‚ÄãDdistùëîsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤‚ãÖ2#ùê∑\mbox{{dist}}(g,g^{\prime})=2\cdot\#D and, in addition, g‚äï(‚®ÅD‚Ä≤)‚ààKdirect-sumùëîdirect-sumsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùêæg\oplus(\bigoplus D^{\prime})\in K for every subset D‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑‚Ä≤D^{\prime} of Dùê∑D.

Proof

Since KùêæK is a Kekul√© cell, we can choose a graph Gùê∫G with P=p‚ÄãGùëÉùëùùê∫P=pG and K=KP‚Äã(G)ùêæKPùê∫K=\mbox{{KP}}(G). Let gùëîg, g‚Ä≤‚ààKsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùêæg^{\prime}\in K. We can take Kekul√© states WùëäW and W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} of Gùê∫G so that g=(W|P)ùëîconditionalùëäùëÉg=(W|P) and g‚Ä≤=(W‚Ä≤|P)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤conditionalsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùëÉg^{\prime}=(W^{\prime}|P). Let (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W) be the alternating curve of Theorem 2.1(a) with C=W‚äïW‚Ä≤ùê∂direct-sumùëäsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤C=W\oplus W^{\prime}. Curve Cùê∂C is the disjoint union of simple paths between ports, and cycles. Assume that C0subscriptùê∂0C_{0}, ‚Ä¶, Cd‚àí1subscriptùê∂ùëë1C_{d-1} are the components of Cùê∂C that are the simple paths. Then (Ci,W)subscriptùê∂ùëñùëä(C_{i},W) is an alternating path between ports for every i<dùëñùëëi<d.

For each index iùëñi, let cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i} be the channel that consists of the endpoints of path Cisubscriptùê∂ùëñC_{i}. We take D={ci‚à£i<d}ùê∑conditional-setsubscriptùëêùëñùëñùëëD=\{c_{i}\mid i<d\}. Since the paths Cisubscriptùê∂ùëñC_{i} are components of Cùê∂C, they are disjoint. Therefore, the channels in Dùê∑D are disjoint. It is easy to see that g‚Ä≤=g‚äï(‚®ÅD)superscriptùëî‚Ä≤direct-sumùëîdirect-sumùê∑g^{\prime}=g\oplus(\bigoplus D) and dist‚Äã(g,g‚Ä≤)=2‚ãÖ#‚ÄãDdistùëîsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤‚ãÖ2#ùê∑\mbox{{dist}}(g,g^{\prime})=2\cdot\#D. Repeated application of Theorem 2.1(b) yields that g‚äï(‚®ÅD‚Ä≤)‚ààKP‚Äã(G)=Kdirect-sumùëîdirect-sumsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤KPùê∫ùêæg\oplus(\bigoplus D^{\prime})\in\mbox{{KP}}(G)=K for every subset D‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑‚Ä≤D^{\prime} of Dùê∑D. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

This result implies that, in a Kekul√© cell, every two elements differ by a set of disjoint channels in such a way that all intermediate combinations (of one element with some of the channels) also belong to the cell.

A port p‚ààPùëùùëÉp\in P is called flexible for a cell KùêæK if there are gùëîg, g‚Ä≤‚ààKsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùêæg^{\prime}\in K with p‚ààg‚àñg‚Ä≤ùëùùëîsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤p\in g\setminus g^{\prime}. Nonflexible ports do not participate in any switching behaviour. We are therefore only interested in the flexible ports. Now, Theorem 2.4 also implies the following result.

Corollary 2

Let KùêæK be a Kekul√© cell in Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P).
(a) Let pùëùp be a flexible port for KùêæK. For any g‚ààKùëîùêæg\in K, there is a channel cùëêc with p‚ààcùëùùëêp\in c and g‚äïc‚ààKdirect-sumùëîùëêùêæg\oplus c\in K.
(b) When KùêæK has a flexible port, it has to have at least two flexible ports.

Since nonflexible ports are useless for the application we have in mind, we define a cell to be flexible if all ports are flexible. We eliminate the nonflexible ports in the following way. Let QùëÑQ be the set of flexible ports of KùêæK. Then the flexible cell flex‚Äã(K)‚äÜPow‚Äã(Q)flexùêæPowùëÑ\mbox{{flex}}(K)\subseteq\mbox{{Pow}}(Q) is defined by flex‚Äã(K)={g‚à©Q‚à£g‚ààK}flexùêæconditional-setùëîùëÑùëîùêæ\mbox{{flex}}(K)=\{g\cap Q\mid g\in K\}.

It is easy to see that, indeed, cell flex‚Äã(K)flexùêæ\mbox{{flex}}(K) is flexible, i.e., all ports p‚ààQùëùùëÑp\in Q are flexible for flex‚Äã(K)flexùêæ\mbox{{flex}}(K). The restriction function g‚Ü¶g‚à©Qmaps-toùëîùëîùëÑg\mapsto g\cap Q is a bijective correspondence between KùêæK and flex‚Äã(K)flexùêæ\mbox{{flex}}(K).

Theorem 2.5

The cell flex‚Äã(K)flexùêæ\mbox{{flex}}(K) is Kekul√© if and only if the cell KùêæK is Kekul√©.

Proof

First assume that cell KùêæK is Kekul√©. We can therefore choose a graph Gùê∫G with P=p‚ÄãGùëÉùëùùê∫P=pG and K=KP‚Äã(G)ùêæKPùê∫K=\mbox{{KP}}(G). We define an edge of graph Gùê∫G to be flexible if there are Kekul√© states WùëäW and W‚Ä≤superscriptùëä‚Ä≤W^{\prime} of Gùê∫G with e‚ààW‚àñW‚Ä≤ùëíùëäsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤e\in W\setminus W^{\prime}. Let G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} be the subgraph of the flexible edges of Gùê∫G.

2.5 Transforming the graph while preserving its Kekul√© cell

The next result allows us to simplify graphs while retaining the Kekul√© cell.

Theorem 2.6

Let graph Gùê∫G have a node u0subscriptùë¢0u_{0} with precisely two neighbour nodes u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}. Assume that u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2} are both internal. Let graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} be obtained from Gùê∫G by removing u0subscriptùë¢0u_{0} and its two incident edges and merging the nodes u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2} into a new node uùë¢u. If there is an edge between u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}, it is removed since it would become a self-loop. For every node v‚â†u0ùë£subscriptùë¢0v\neq u_{0} that is a common neighbour of u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}, the two edges linking vùë£v to u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2} are identified, since multiple edges are not allowed.

Consequently, the degree of uùë¢u is d1+d2‚àí2‚àí2‚Äãa‚àíbsubscriptùëë1subscriptùëë222ùëéùëèd_{1}+d_{2}-2-2a-b, where d1subscriptùëë1d_{1} and d2subscriptùëë2d_{2} are the degrees of u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}, respectively, and a‚àà{0,1}ùëé01a\in\{0,1\} is the number of edges between u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}, and b‚àà‚Ñïùëè‚Ñïb\in\mbox{$\mathbb{N}$} is the number of common neighbours of u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2} different from u0subscriptùë¢0u_{0}. In all cases, KP‚Äã(G‚Ä≤)=KP‚Äã(G)KPsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤KPùê∫\mbox{{KP}}(G^{\prime})=\mbox{{KP}}(G).

Proof

Let e1subscriptùëí1e_{1} and e2subscriptùëí2e_{2} be the edges linking u0subscriptùë¢0u_{0} with u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}, respectively. If it exists, let e0subscriptùëí0e_{0} be the edge between u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}. Let E1subscriptùê∏1E_{1} be the set of the other edges incident with u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and let E2subscriptùê∏2E_{2} be the set of the other edges incident with u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2}. Every Kekul√© state WùëäW of Gùê∫G has e1‚ààWsubscriptùëí1ùëäe_{1}\in W if and only if e2‚àâWsubscriptùëí2ùëäe_{2}\notin W. It follows that WùëäW contains precisely one of the edges in E1‚à™E2subscriptùê∏1subscriptùê∏2E_{1}\cup E_{2} and that e0‚àâWsubscriptùëí0ùëäe_{0}\notin W if e0subscriptùëí0e_{0} exists. We can therefore transform WùëäW into a Kekul√© state of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} with the same values on all remaining edges. The details about neighbour vùë£v are left to the reader. It is easy to see that all Kekul√© states of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} are obtained in this way. Because the transformation does not change the ports, the Kekul√© cells of Gùê∫G and G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} are equal. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

This result can also be used in the other direction, i.e., starting with graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}. In this way, it can serve to split a node with a high degree into two nodes with a lower degree. By first merging and then splitting, it can also be used to shift edges between nodes u1subscriptùë¢1u_{1} and u2subscriptùë¢2u_{2} in a similar way as with operation Op.vii of [17, section 3.3.1].

2.6 Classification of small Kekul√© cells

We define the Hamming diameter of a cell KùêæK as the maximum Hamming distance between its elements: diam‚Äã(K)=max‚Äã{dist‚Äã(k,k‚Ä≤)‚à£k,k‚Ä≤‚ààK}diamùêæmaxconditional-setdistùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤ùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤ùêæ\mbox{{diam}}(K)=\mbox{{max}}\{\mbox{{dist}}(k,k^{\prime})\mid k,k^{\prime}\in K\}. We clearly have diam‚Äã(K)‚â§#‚ÄãPdiamùêæ#ùëÉ\mbox{{diam}}(K)\leq\#P. Cell KùêæK has flexible ports if and only if diam‚Äã(K)>0diamùêæ0\mbox{{diam}}(K)>0. By Theorem 2.4, the diameter of a Kekul√© cell is always even. We use these observations here to determine all flexible Kekul√© cells with at most 4 ports.

For a fixed set PùëÉP of ports, we define the cell K1={{p}‚à£p‚ààP}subscriptùêæ1conditional-setùëùùëùùëÉK_{1}=\{\{p\}\mid p\in P\}. If PùëÉP has more than one element, K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1} has diameter 2.

Lemma 1

Let KùêæK be a flexible cell in Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) with diameter 2. Assume that #‚ÄãP‚â†3#ùëÉ3\#P\neq 3. Then KùêæK is a Kekul√© cell if and only if there is g‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ùëîPowùëÉg\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P) such that K=g‚äïK1ùêædirect-sumùëîsubscriptùêæ1K=g\oplus K_{1}.

Proof

We first show that K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1} is a Kekul√© cell. For this purpose, we take the graph Gùê∫G with one internal node connected to all ports (a so-called star). Every Kekul√© state WùëäW of Gùê∫G contains precisely one edge. The corresponding port assignment contains precisely one port. Since Kekul√© cells can be translated, this proves the if part of the assertion.

Conversely, let KùêæK be a Kekul√© cell with diameter 2. By translation, we may assume that ‚àÖ‚ààKùêæ\emptyset\in K. By Corollary 2(a) with g=‚àÖùëîg=\emptyset, for every p‚ààPùëùùëÉp\in P, there is some q‚â†pùëûùëùq\neq p with {p,q}‚ààKùëùùëûùêæ\{p,q\}\in K. Using #‚ÄãP‚â†3#ùëÉ3\#P\neq 3 and diam‚Äã(K)=2diamùêæ2\mbox{{diam}}(K)=2, one can show that there is one port p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} such that KùêæK consists of the channels {p0,q}subscriptùëù0ùëû\{p_{0},q\} for all ports q‚â†p0ùëûsubscriptùëù0q\neq p_{0}. This implies that K={p0}‚äïK1ùêædirect-sumsubscriptùëù0subscriptùêæ1K=\{p_{0}\}\oplus K_{1}. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Remark 2

A star graph with >4absent4>4 ports is not commonly found in carbon chemistry, but by (repeated) application of Theorem 2.6, one can easily find alternatives. An example where one can use a tree graph for the five port situation is given below. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Remark 3

In the case of #‚ÄãP=3#ùëÉ3\#P=3, all flexible Kekul√© cells have diameter 2. In this case, there are two classes of flexible Kekul√© cells: the translates of K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1} of Lemma 1 and the translates of Even‚Äã(P)EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Even}}(P). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Lemma 2

For the converse implication (only if), we may assume that KùêæK satisfies K0‚äÜK‚äÜEven‚Äã(P)subscriptùêæ0ùêæEvenùëÉK_{0}\subseteq K\subseteq\mbox{{Even}}(P) where K0={‚àÖ,{a,b},{c,d},{a,b,c,d}}subscriptùêæ0ùëéùëèùëêùëëùëéùëèùëêùëëK_{0}=\{\emptyset,\{a,b\},\{c,d\},\{a,b,c,d\}\}. Remark 4

This proof shows that the Kekul√© cells with 4 ports and diameter 4 can all be realized by subgraphs of the graph which is called Œî4subscriptŒî4\Delta_{4} in section 4. It seems likely that this result can be generalized in some way, but at this point we do not see how.

3 Semi-Kekul√© States

This section serves as an aside to provide a context in which Kekul√© states are special cases. We weaken the condition for Kekul√© states to a linear condition over the field with two elements. This simplifies the mathematics, since the whole theory of linear equations becomes available.

For an integer xùë•x, we write x‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2ùë•¬†mod¬†2x\mbox{{\ mod }}2 to denote the remainder of xùë•x upon integer division by 2. It follows that x‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2=0ùë•¬†mod¬†20x\mbox{{\ mod }}2=0 (or 111) if and only if xùë•x is even (or odd, respectively). For integers xùë•x and yùë¶y, we define x‚äïy=(x+y)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2direct-sumùë•ùë¶ùë•ùë¶¬†mod¬†2x\oplus y=(x+y)\mbox{{\ mod }}2.

A node in a graph is called even/odd if its degree in the graph is even/odd. A subgraph WùëäW of Gùê∫G is called a semi-Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G if every internal node of Gùê∫G is an odd node of WùëäW. Clearly, every Kekul√© state is a semi-Kekul√© state, but not vice versa.

For any graph Gùê∫G, we define odd‚Äã(G)oddùê∫\mbox{{odd}}(G) to be the set of odd nodes of Gùê∫G. Therefore, WùëäW is a semi-Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G if and only if i‚ÄãG‚äÜodd‚Äã(W)ùëñùê∫oddùëäiG\subseteq\mbox{{odd}}(W). Since every edge contributes twice to the degree of a node, the sum of the degrees of the nodes is twice the number of edges. It is therefore even. Since the sum of the degrees at the even nodes is also even, it follows that the sum of the degrees of the odd nodes is even. Since every odd node contributes an odd number, it follows that the number of odd nodes is even: #‚Äãodd‚Äã(G)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2=0#oddùê∫¬†mod¬†20\#\mbox{{odd}}(G)\mbox{{\ mod }}2=0 for every graph Gùê∫G.

3.1 There are enough semi-Kekul√© states

Let the signature of a graph Gùê∫G be defined as the number s‚ÄãG=(#‚Äãi‚ÄãG)‚Äãmod¬†‚Äã2ùë†ùê∫#ùëñùê∫mod¬†2sG=(\#iG)\,\mbox{{mod }}2. In other words, the signature is 0 or 1, depending on whether the number of internal nodes is even or odd. To formulate the next result conveniently, we define Pow‚Äã(P)0=Even‚Äã(P)PowsubscriptùëÉ0EvenùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{0}=\mbox{{Even}}(P) and Pow‚Äã(P)1=Odd‚Äã(P)PowsubscriptùëÉ1OddùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{1}=\mbox{{Odd}}(P), see section 2.3.

Theorem 3.1

Let Gùê∫G be a graph with port set P=p‚ÄãGùëÉùëùùê∫P=pG and signature Œµ=s‚ÄãGùúÄùë†ùê∫{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}=sG.
(a) Let WùëäW be a semi-Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G. Then (W|P)‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ŒµconditionalùëäùëÉPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ(W|P)\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}.
(b) Conversely, let g‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ŒµùëîPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄg\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}. Assume that graph Gùê∫G is connected. Then Gùê∫G has a semi-Kekul√© state WùëäW with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g.

Proof

For any subgraph WùëäW of Gùê∫G, we define the set of violating nodes by vio‚Äã(W)=i‚ÄãG‚àñodd‚Äã(W)vioùëäùëñùê∫oddùëä\mbox{{vio}}(W)=iG\setminus\mbox{{odd}}(W). Clearly, WùëäW is semi-Kekul√© if and only if vio‚Äã(W)vioùëä\mbox{{vio}}(W) is empty.

On the other hand, we have (W|P)=P‚à©n‚ÄãW=odd‚Äã(W)‚àñi‚ÄãGconditionalùëäùëÉùëÉùëõùëäoddùëäùëñùê∫(W|P)=P\cap nW=\mbox{{odd}}(W)\setminus iG, since ports are nodes that belong to precisely one edge. It follows that

#‚Äãvio‚Äã(W)+#‚Äã(W|P)=#‚Äã(i‚ÄãG‚äïodd‚Äã(W))#vioùëä#conditionalùëäùëÉ#direct-sumùëñùê∫oddùëä\#\mbox{{vio}}(W)+\#(W|P)=\#(iG\oplus\mbox{{odd}}(W))
=#‚Äãi‚ÄãG+#‚Äãodd‚Äã(W)‚àí2‚ãÖ#‚Äã(i‚ÄãG‚à©odd‚Äã(W))absent#ùëñùê∫#oddùëä‚ãÖ2#ùëñùê∫oddùëä=\;\#iG+\#\mbox{{odd}}(W)-2\cdot\#(iG\cap\mbox{{odd}}(W)) .

Since #‚Äãodd‚Äã(W)#oddùëä\#\mbox{{odd}}(W) is even and #‚Äãi‚ÄãG‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2=Œµ#ùëñùê∫¬†mod¬†2ùúÄ\#iG\mbox{{\ mod }}2={\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}, this implies that

(*) (#‚Äãvio‚Äã(W)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2)‚äï(#‚Äã(W|P)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2)=Œµdirect-sum#vioùëä¬†mod¬†2#conditionalùëäùëÉ¬†mod¬†2ùúÄ(\#\mbox{{vio}}(W)\mbox{{\ mod }}2)\oplus(\#(W|P)\mbox{{\ mod }}2)={\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} .

If WùëäW is semi-Kekul√©, vio‚Äã(W)vioùëä\mbox{{vio}}(W) is empty, so that #‚Äã(W|P)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2=Œµ#conditionalùëäùëÉ¬†mod¬†2ùúÄ\#(W|P)\mbox{{\ mod }}2={\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}, i.e., (W|P)‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ŒµconditionalùëäùëÉPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ(W|P)\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}. This proves part (a).

Conversely, assume that #‚Äãg‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2=Œµ#ùëî¬†mod¬†2ùúÄ\#g\mbox{{\ mod }}2={\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}. We can define some subgraph WùëäW of Gùê∫G with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g. Then the righthand summand of (*) equals ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon. It follows that the number of elements of vio‚Äã(W)vioùëä\mbox{{vio}}(W) is even. If it is positive, then we can choose two different nodes uùë¢u and v‚ààvio‚Äã(W)ùë£vioùëäv\in\mbox{{vio}}(W). Since VùëâV is connected, we can choose a simple path Cùê∂C from uùë¢u to vùë£v in Gùê∫G, and replace WùëäW by W‚Ä≤=W‚äïCsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤direct-sumùëäùê∂W^{\prime}=W\oplus C, which satisfies vio‚Äã(W‚Ä≤)=vio‚Äã(W)‚àñ{u,v}viosuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤vioùëäùë¢ùë£\mbox{{vio}}(W^{\prime})=\mbox{{vio}}(W)\setminus\{u,v\} and W‚Ä≤|P=gconditionalsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùëÉùëîW^{\prime}|P=g. We can continue in this way until vio‚Äã(W)vioùëä\mbox{{vio}}(W) is empty. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

For a port assignment gùëîg in a connected graph, Theorem 3.1 implies that the condition g‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ŒµùëîPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄg\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} is necessary and sufficient for the existence of a semi-Kekul√© state WùëäW with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g. This also implies that this is a necessary condition for the existence of a Kekul√© state WùëäW with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g. In section 4, we will describe graphs in which this condition is not only necessary but also sufficient.

3.2 The homogeneous semi-Kekul√© kernel

Let ùîπùîπ\mathbb{B}¬†(pronounced Bit) be the set of the two elements 0 and 1, with the addition ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus described above and an ordinary multiplication. This is a field, i.e., an algebraic structure with the usual laws for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by nonzero elements. It follows that the whole theory of vector spaces and linear equations is applicable over ùîπùîπ\mathbb{B}.

In particular, for a set PùëÉP, the additive group Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) is a vector space over ùîπùîπ\mathbb{B}¬†of dimension #‚ÄãP#ùëÉ\#P. The easiest way to see this is to identify a subset g‚äÜPùëîùëÉg\subseteq P with its characteristic function œágsubscriptùúíùëî\chi_{g} given by œág‚Äã(p)=1subscriptùúíùëîùëù1\chi_{g}(p)=1 if p‚ààgùëùùëîp\in g and œág‚Äã(p)=0subscriptùúíùëîùëù0\chi_{g}(p)=0 if p‚àâgùëùùëîp\notin g. In this way Pow‚Äã(P)PowùëÉ\mbox{{Pow}}(P) is identified with the set of functions P‚Üíùîπ‚ÜíùëÉùîπP\to\mbox{$\mathbb{B}$}. The symmetric difference operator ‚äïdirect-sum\oplus corresponds to the operator on functions given by (f‚äïg)‚Äã(p)=f‚Äã(p)‚äïg‚Äã(p)direct-sumùëìùëîùëùdirect-sumùëìùëùùëîùëù(f\oplus g)(p)=f(p)\oplus g(p).

The vector space Pow‚Äã(G)Powùê∫\mbox{{Pow}}(G) is introduced in the same way. We define the homogeneous semi-Kekul√© kernel, HSK‚Äã(G)HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G), of Gùê∫G to be the set of subgraphs WùëäW for which all nodes are even:

HSK‚Äã(G)={W‚ààPow‚Äã(G)‚à£odd‚Äã(W)=‚àÖ}HSKùê∫conditional-setùëäPowùê∫oddùëä\mbox{{HSK}}(G)=\{W\in\mbox{{Pow}}(G)\mid\mbox{{odd}}(W)=\emptyset\} .

It is easy to see that HSK is a linear subspace of Pow‚Äã(G)Powùê∫\mbox{{Pow}}(G).

If an inhomogeneous system of linear equations has a solution W0subscriptùëä0W_{0}, the set of all its solutions is of the form W0‚äïHdirect-sumsubscriptùëä0ùêªW_{0}\oplus H, where HùêªH is the set of solutions of the homogeneous linear system. It follows that, given one semi-Kekul√© state W0subscriptùëä0W_{0} of Gùê∫G, the set of semi-Kekul√© states with the same port assignment as W0subscriptùëä0W_{0} is equal to W0‚äïHSK‚Äã(G)={W0‚äïW‚à£W‚ààHSK‚Äã(G)}direct-sumsubscriptùëä0HSKùê∫conditional-setdirect-sumsubscriptùëä0ùëäùëäHSKùê∫W_{0}\oplus\mbox{{HSK}}(G)=\{W_{0}\oplus W\mid W\in\mbox{{HSK}}(G)\}.

A graph is called a tree if it is connected and has no connected proper subgraph with the same set of nodes. Every connected graph has a spanning tree, i.e., a subgraph with the same nodes which is a tree (just remove edges one by one until you would cause disconnectedness).

Theorem 3.2

Let graph Gùê∫G be connected. The vector space HSK‚Äã(G)HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G) over ùîπùîπ\mathbb{B} has dimension #‚ÄãG+1‚àí#‚Äãn‚ÄãG#ùê∫1#ùëõùê∫\#G+1-\#nG. It has a basis over ùîπùîπ\mathbb{B}¬†that consists of cycles of Gùê∫G.

Proof

First, assume that Gùê∫G is a tree. Then the number of nodes is one plus the number of edges, as is well-known in graph theory. So we have #‚Äãn‚ÄãG=#‚ÄãG+1#ùëõùê∫#ùê∫1\#nG=\#G+1. On the other hand, since Gùê∫G is a tree, one can prove by induction on the size of the tree that HSK‚Äã(G)={‚àÖ}HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G)=\{\emptyset\}. This implies the assertion for the case that Gùê∫G is a tree.

We now proceed by induction on the number of edges. Let graph Gùê∫G be given. We may assume that Gùê∫G is connected and not a tree. Therefore Gùê∫G contains an edge eùëíe, such that removal of eùëíe yields a connected graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}. By induction, the space HSK‚Äã(G‚Ä≤)HSKsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}) of the subgraphs WùëäW of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} with odd‚Äã(W)oddùëä\mbox{{odd}}(W) empty has dimension #‚ÄãG‚àí#‚Äãn‚ÄãG#ùê∫#ùëõùê∫\#G-\#nG and a basis BùêµB that consists of cycles of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}. Since graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is connected, edge eùëíe is contained in a cycle Cùê∂C of graph Gùê∫G. Now Cùê∂C is an element of HSK‚Äã(G)‚àñHSK‚Äã(G‚Ä≤)HSKùê∫HSKsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤\mbox{{HSK}}(G)\setminus\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}). Therefore HSK‚Äã(G‚Ä≤)HSKsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}) is a proper subset of HSK‚Äã(G)HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G). Since HSK‚Äã(G‚Ä≤)HSKsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}) is the subset of HSK‚Äã(G)HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G) given by the single equation that corresponds to the condition e‚àâWùëíùëäe\notin W, it follows that dim‚Äã(HSK‚Äã(G))=1+dim‚Äã(HSK‚Äã(G‚Ä≤))=#‚ÄãG+1‚àí#‚Äãn‚ÄãGdimHSKùê∫1dimHSKsuperscriptùê∫‚Ä≤#ùê∫1#ùëõùê∫\mbox{{dim}}(\mbox{{HSK}}(G))=1+\mbox{{dim}}(\mbox{{HSK}}(G^{\prime}))=\#G+1-\#nG and that B‚à™{C}ùêµùê∂B\cup\{C\} is a basis of HSK‚Äã(G)HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

This result was inspired by the observation that, for each of the graphs considered in Figures 5.7 and 5.8 of [17], the set HSK‚Äã(G)HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G) has 8 elements.

Corollary 3

Let Gùê∫G be connected. Let C0subscriptùê∂0C_{0}, ‚Ä¶, Cr‚àí1subscriptùê∂ùëü1C_{r-1} be cycles in Gùê∫G such that r=#‚ÄãG+1‚àí#‚Äãn‚ÄãGùëü#ùê∫1#ùëõùê∫r=\#G+1-\#nG and that C0subscriptùê∂0C_{0}, ‚Ä¶, Cr‚àí1subscriptùê∂ùëü1C_{r-1} are linearly independent over ùîπùîπ\mathbb{B}.
(a) Then C0subscriptùê∂0C_{0}, ‚Ä¶, Cr‚àí1subscriptùê∂ùëü1C_{r-1} form a basis of HSK‚Äã(G)HSKùê∫\mbox{{HSK}}(G).
(b) Let P=p‚ÄãGùëÉùëùùê∫P=pG and Œµ=s‚ÄãGùúÄùë†ùê∫{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}=sG. For any g‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ŒµùëîPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄg\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}, there are precisely 2rsuperscript2ùëü2^{r} semi-Kekul√© states WùëäW with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g.

From part (b) it follows that the number of Kekul√© states with a given port assignment is ‚â§2rabsentsuperscript2ùëü\leq 2^{r}.

Usually, it is very easy to find enough linearly independent cycles to obtain a basis for HSK with Corollary 3, and to find simple paths between different ports. Since the constructive proof of Theorem 3.1 is not very efficient, we prefer to apply Gauss elimination to the inhomogeneous system to find semi-Kekul√© states.

Complexity. The problem to determine some Kekul√© state for a given graph with given port assignment, has a complicated but efficient solution with complexity ùí™‚Äã(#‚ÄãE‚ãÖ#‚ÄãV)ùí™‚ãÖ#ùê∏#ùëâ{\cal O}(\#E\cdot\sqrt{\#V}) [10]. All semi-Kekul√© states can easily be found in time ùí™‚Äã(#‚ÄãE‚ãÖ#‚ÄãV)ùí™‚ãÖ#ùê∏#ùëâ{\cal O}(\#E\cdot\#V). The above approach leads to an algorithm to determine all Kekul√© states in time ùí™‚Äã(#‚ÄãE‚ãÖ(#‚ÄãV+2r))ùí™‚ãÖ#ùê∏#ùëâsuperscript2ùëü{\cal O}(\#E\cdot(\#V+2^{r})) where rùëür is as in Corollary 3. In the applications, this is quite feasible, since rùëür tends to be rather small.

4 Omniconjugated Graphs

Van der Veen et al.¬†[18] have defined nùëõn-port (‚Äònùëõn-terminal‚Äô) œÄùúã\pi-conjugated molecules, with n‚â•3ùëõ3n\geq 3, as omniconjugated of type A, if direct linear conjugated pathways are present between all pairs of ports in all states of the ports. We now formalize the principles of such systems in a mathematical way.

We define a graph Gùê∫G with signature ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon to be omniconjugated if P=p‚ÄãGùëÉùëùùê∫P=pG has at least two elements and the Kekul√© cell of Gùê∫G is Pow‚Äã(P)ŒµPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} (i.e., maximal). Note that our concept omniconjugated represents what is called ‚Äúomniconjugated of Type A‚Äù in [18, 17].

Corollary 4

Let Gùê∫G be omniconjugated. Let WùëäW be a Kekul√© state of Gùê∫G. Let pùëùp and qùëûq be two different ports of Gùê∫G. Then Gùê∫G has an alternating curve (C,W)ùê∂ùëä(C,W), such that Cùê∂C is a simple path from pùëùp to qùëûq.

Proof

Since (W|P)‚äï{p,q}‚ààPow‚Äã(P)Œµdirect-sumconditionalùëäùëÉùëùùëûPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ(W|P)\oplus\{p,q\}\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}, and the graph is omniconjugated, the assertion follows from Theorem 2.2. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

The corollary means that all channels of an omniconjugated graph are always open (low resistance). Conversely, if graph Gùê∫G has at least one Kekul√© state and all channels are always open, it is omniconjugated.

For every set PùëÉP with at least two elements, omniconjugated graphs exist. This is shown as follows. Let A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2} be the graph that consists of one edge with its two nodes. The two nodes are ports. In this case, Œµ=0ùúÄ0{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}=0 and Pow‚Äã(P)ŒµPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} contains the empty subgraph and the full subgraph which are both Kekul√© states. Therefore A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2} is omniconjugated. More generally, the linear graph Ansubscriptùê¥ùëõA_{n} of n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 consecutive nodes and n‚àí1ùëõ1n-1 edges is also omniconjugated (the name Ansubscriptùê¥ùëõA_{n} comes from the classification of Dynkin diagrams).

The smallest omniconjugated graph with ‚â•3absent3\geq 3 ports is the graph Œî3subscriptŒî3\Delta_{3} with 3 ports, and three internal nodes of degree 3 that form a triangle. More generally, let Gnsubscriptùê∫ùëõG_{n} for n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 be the complete graph with nùëõn nodes and (n2)binomialùëõ2{n\choose 2} edges. Let ŒînsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta_{n} be the graph obtained from Gnsubscriptùê∫ùëõG_{n} by attaching a port via an edge to every node of Gnsubscriptùê∫ùëõG_{n}. So, ŒînsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta_{n} has 2‚Äãn2ùëõ2n nodes and (n2)+nbinomialùëõ2ùëõ{n\choose 2}+n edges. Note that Œî2=A4subscriptŒî2subscriptùê¥4\Delta_{2}=A_{4} and that Œî4subscriptŒî4\Delta_{4} is the graph used for K5subscriptùêæ5K_{5} in the proof of Lemma 2. We leave it to the reader to verify that all graphs ŒînsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta_{n} with n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 are omniconjugated. Conversely, we have:

Lemma 3

Let Gùê∫G be a graph with n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 nodes. Let graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} be obtained from Gùê∫G by attaching a port via an edge to every node of Gùê∫G. Assume that G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is omniconjugated. Then Gùê∫G is a complete graph.

Proof

Since Gùê∫G has no isolated nodes, all nodes of Gùê∫G are internal nodes of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}, and G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} has nùëõn ports. Therefore, the signature ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is n‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2ùëõ¬†mod¬†2n\mbox{{\ mod }}2. Let PùëÉP be the set of ports of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}.

It suffices to prove that every pair of different nodes of Gùê∫G is linked in Gùê∫G. Let u‚â†vùë¢ùë£u\neq v be nodes of Gùê∫G. Let pùëùp and qùëûq be the unique ports of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} linked to uùë¢u and vùë£v, respectively. Let gùëîg be the port assignment of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} given by g=P‚àñ{p,q}ùëîùëÉùëùùëûg=P\setminus\{p,q\}. We have g‚ààPow‚Äã(P)ŒµùëîPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄg\in\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} since (n‚àí2)‚Äã¬†mod¬†‚Äã2=Œµùëõ2¬†mod¬†2ùúÄ(n-2)\mbox{{\ mod }}2={\mbox{$\varepsilon$}}.

Since it is omniconjugated, graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} has a Kekul√© state WùëäW with (W|P)=gconditionalùëäùëÉùëî(W|P)=g. Every edge eùëíe that contains a port r‚ààgùëüùëîr\in g is in WùëäW. Since WùëäW is a Kekul√© state of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}, it follows that e‚àâWùëíùëäe\notin W for every edge e‚ààGùëíùê∫e\in G that contains some node of Gùê∫G other than uùë¢u and vùë£v. The two edges eùëíe of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} incident with pùëùp and qùëûq are not in WùëäW. Since WùëäW is a Kekul√© state of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}, it follows that uùë¢u is element of a unique edge eùëíe of WùëäW. It follows that vùë£v is the other endpoint of eùëíe. This proves that uùë¢u and vùë£v are linked in Gùê∫G. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Section 3.3.1 of [17] presents a topological design program for omniconjugated models that have properties similar to those of our omniconjugated graphs. We transfer this idea to omniconjugated graphs in the following way.

Starting with an omniconjugated graph Gùê∫G, the question is: what kinds of operations on Gùê∫G are allowed that preserve its property of being omnicojugated? It turns out that operations like Op.vi and Op.vii of [17] are allowed because of Theorem 2.6. It is also easy to see that the operations Op.ii, Op.v, and Op.iv are preserved in the following sense:

Lemma 4

Let Gùê∫G be an omniconjugated graph. Let G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} be obtained from Gùê∫G by applying the following two types of operations:
Op.ii. Add arbitrary edges between internal nodes.
Op.v. Replace the edge to a port by two edges and a node of degree 2.
Then G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is omniconjugated.

Lemma 5

Op.iv. Let G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} be a graph with port p‚Ä≤superscriptùëù‚Ä≤p^{\prime} and let G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤‚Ä≤G^{\prime\prime} be a graph with port p‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùëù‚Ä≤‚Ä≤p^{\prime\prime}. Let graph Gùê∫G be obtained from G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} and G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤‚Ä≤G^{\prime\prime} by removing the two ports and identifying their incident edges. Then Gùê∫G is omniconjugated if and only if G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} and G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤‚Ä≤G^{\prime\prime} are omniconjugated.

For example, as indicated in [17, Scheme 3.1], we can apply Op.ii twice to the basic model A6subscriptùê¥6A_{6} to obtain the basic model B, which is therefore also omniconjugated.

Starting with graph Œî3subscriptŒî3\Delta_{3}, one can apply Op.iv to obtain omniconjugated graphs with arbitrary many ports. For this purpose, we therefore do not need the graphs ŒînsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta_{n} with n>3ùëõ3n>3.

In Theorem 2.6, we described a transformation from a graph Gùê∫G into a graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} that has the same Kekul√© cell. It follows that G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is omniconjugated if and only if Gùê∫G is omniconjugated. We conjecture that every omniconjugated graph in which all nodes have degree ‚â§3absent3\leq 3 can be obtained by starting with the basic models A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2} and Œî3subscriptŒî3\Delta_{3} and applying Theorem 2.6 and the Lemmas 4 and 5.

5 Functional Cells and Controlled Switches

In this section, we build upon the ideas of Chapter 6 of [17]. The idea of this chapter is that an alternating path between a pair of ports forms an open channel, and that the absence of any alternating path means closure of the channel.

A cell K‚äÜPow‚Äã(P)ùêæPowùëÉK\subseteq\mbox{{Pow}}(P) becomes a functional cell by specifying an initial element k0‚ààKsubscriptùëò0ùêæk_{0}\in K and a linearly independent system of channels to probe and modify the current element of the cell. See the example given at the end of section 2.2.

5.1 A cell for the conjunction

Section 6.3 of [17] contains 15 of the 16 binary boolean operators implemented with pyracylene-based structures bearing six ports in various patterns. The only missing operator is the conjunction. Since ¬¨A‚àßBùê¥ùêµ\neg A\land B is available in structure 6.8 (p.¬†140) of [17], the conjunction can be realized in pyracylene by taking a nonzero initial state.

We now sketch an approach that yields a simpler graph. We first design the functional cell. Let k0=‚àÖsubscriptùëò0k_{0}=\emptyset be the initial element. In the style of [17], we choose two input channels Aùê¥A and BùêµB and a test channel TùëáT. Since we want to model the conjunction of the inputs, test channel TùëáT must be open if and only if both input channels are signalled. Therefore, the cell KùêæK must contain the elements ‚àÖ\emptyset, Aùê¥A, BùêµB, A‚äïBdirect-sumùê¥ùêµA\oplus B, and A‚äïB‚äïTdirect-sumùê¥ùêµùëáA\oplus B\oplus T. Since channel TùëáT must be closed in the states ‚àÖ\emptyset, Aùê¥A, BùêµB, cell KùêæK must not contain the elements TùëáT, A‚äïTdirect-sumùê¥ùëáA\oplus T, and B‚äïTdirect-sumùêµùëáB\oplus T.

Since all eight port assignments mentioned should be different, the smallest candidate is a cell with 4 ports and 5 elements. The solution happens to occur as cell K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1} in the classification in the proof of Lemma 2 when we take A={a,b}ùê¥ùëéùëèA=\{a,b\}, B={c,d}ùêµùëêùëëB=\{c,d\}, and T={b,d}ùëáùëèùëëT=\{b,d\}.

A disadvantage of this solution is that both ports of test channel T={b,d}ùëáùëèùëëT=\{b,d\} are used in the input channels. It may be difficult to independently signal Aùê¥A and BùêµB and probe TùëáT.

5.2 Reading output without disabling the switch

The example discussed above has an even more fundamental problem, which it shares with the example in section 2.2 and the results of [17]: if the test whether the output channel TùëáT is open is performed by signalling the channel, the cell moves to a state where it no longer satisfies its specification.

The point is discussed by [17] on page 149. She distinguishes signalling a channel by sending a soliton through it and reading a channel by means of a polaron. A polaron can be thought of as a double soliton [14]. In order to use the output of one cell as an input of another cell, we would like to read the output by means of solitons. This, however, requires that signalling the output channel leaves the cell in a state equivalent to the state before the output was read.

In the start state, and in all states reachable before the output is read, all inputs should be possible. In some but not all of these states, the output channel TùëáT should be open. This implies that signalling TùëáT when it is open, can bring the cell in a state where some of the input channels are not open. We therefore have to relax the requirement that input channels are always open, but since input must always be possible, we have to share inputs over more than one channel.

We therefore define an input socket to consist of a pair (A,B)ùê¥ùêµ(A,B) of parallel channels of the form A={p,r}ùê¥ùëùùëüA=\{p,r\}, B={q,r}ùêµùëûùëüB=\{q,r\} for ports pùëùp, qùëûq, and rùëür, such that always either Aùê¥A is open and BùêµB is closed, or vice versa. When a soliton is sent to a socket, it will travel through an open channel of the two.

Remark 5

Note that we require that the two parallel channels of the socket share a port. In fact, if the parallel channels Aùê¥A and BùêµB are disjoint, a soliton sent through the pair can enter via a port of Aùê¥A and exit via a port of BùêµB, so that an unintended channel is signalled. In order to reckon with this possibility, one would have to impose additional requirements. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Example 4

The simplest case, called the Y-cell, has one input socket and one output channel. Let the socket consist of the channels Aùê¥A and BùêµB, and let TùëáT be the output channel. The vectors Aùê¥A, BùêµB, TùëáT are supposed to be linearly independent. We postulate that K=k0‚äïLùêædirect-sumsubscriptùëò0ùêøK=k_{0}\oplus L where L={‚àÖ,A,A‚äïT,A‚äïB‚äïT}ùêøùê¥direct-sumùê¥ùëádirect-sumùê¥ùêµùëáL=\{\emptyset,A,A\oplus T,A\oplus B\oplus T\}.

The state space KùêæK is a translation of LùêøL. Either space consists of 4 states with three possible transitions. In the diagram, a transition indicated with channel cùëêc corresponds to the operation x‚Ü¶x‚äïcmaps-toùë•direct-sumùë•ùëêx\mapsto x\oplus c.

In all states, either channel Aùê¥A or channel BùêµB is available, and toggling this channel opens or closes the output channel TùëáT.

The simplest graph with such a Kekul√© cell is a tree with 5 ports and 3 internal nodes. In this case, the vector space Pow‚Äã(P)ŒµPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} over ùîπùîπ\mathbb{B}¬†has dimension 4 (16 elements). The Kekul√© cell has 8 elements. We use the initial state and the input socket (A,B)ùê¥ùêµ(A,B) and the output channel TùëáT as depicted in the leftmost graph.

In the initial state depicted on the left, only channel Aùê¥A is open. If channel Aùê¥A is signalled, we get in state middle-left where the channels Aùê¥A and TùëáT are open. If TùëáT is signalled there, we get in state middle-right where the channels BùêµB and TùëáT are open. If BùêµB is signalled there, we get in the rightmost state where channel BùêµB is the only open channel.

This state of affairs can also be realized in a pyracylene derivative as shown below. The ports A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1} and T1subscriptùëá1T_{1} start with a double bond in the initial state k0subscriptùëò0k_{0}.

In this case, Pow‚Äã(P)ŒµPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} has dimension 4. The Kekul√© cell has 12 elements. From the start state k0subscriptùëò0k_{0} only four of them are reachable by sending solitons over the channels Aùê¥A, BùêµB, TùëáT, but, e.g., one reaches the origin ‚àÖ\emptyset by sending a soliton from A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1} to T1subscriptùëá1T_{1}. The origin has four different Kekul√© states, whereas k0subscriptùëò0k_{0} and k0‚äïA‚äïB‚äïTdirect-sumsubscriptùëò0ùê¥ùêµùëák_{0}\oplus A\oplus B\oplus T have only two different Kekul√© states. This suggests that the origin is physically much more stable than the physical states corresponding to k0subscriptùëò0k_{0} and k0‚äïA‚äïB‚äïTdirect-sumsubscriptùëò0ùê¥ùêµùëák_{0}\oplus A\oplus B\oplus T. The port assignments k0‚äïAdirect-sumsubscriptùëò0ùê¥k_{0}\oplus A and k0‚äïA‚äïTdirect-sumsubscriptùëò0ùê¥ùëák_{0}\oplus A\oplus T have only one Kekul√© state. It is likely that such Kekul√© states represent less stable physical states. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

Remark 6

Is there a graph Gùê∫G with four ports pùëùp, qùëûq, rùëür, tùë°t, such that the above structure can be realized by taking A={p,r}ùê¥ùëùùëüA=\{p,r\}, B={q,r}ùêµùëûùëüB=\{q,r\}, T={t,r}ùëáùë°ùëüT=\{t,r\}? The answer is no. This follows from Theorem 2.4 by taking g=‚àÖùëîg=\emptyset and g‚Ä≤=A‚äïB‚äïTsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤direct-sumùê¥ùêµùëág^{\prime}=A\oplus B\oplus T. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box

5.3 Splitting for feedback

One may decide that, when an output channel TùëáT is read and toggled, a signal is sent back through TùëáT to reset the cell to its unread state. Since the output should also be sent forward to be used, we need a splitter: a cell with one input channel or socket and two output channels that are both opened when an input signal arrives.

We use an input socket (A,B)ùê¥ùêµ(A,B) and output channels SùëÜS and TùëáT. Let the origin ‚àÖ\emptyset be the initial state. Then the cell must contain 0, Aùê¥A, A‚äïSdirect-sumùê¥ùëÜA\oplus S, A‚äïS‚äïTdirect-sumùê¥ùëÜùëáA\oplus S\oplus T, A‚äïS‚äïT‚äïBdirect-sumùê¥ùëÜùëáùêµA\oplus S\oplus T\oplus B. Since the channels SùëÜS and TùëáT must be closed in states ‚àÖ\emptyset and A‚äïS‚äïT‚äïBdirect-sumùê¥ùëÜùëáùêµA\oplus S\oplus T\oplus B, the cell must not contain SùëÜS, TùëáT, A‚äïS‚äïBdirect-sumùê¥ùëÜùêµA\oplus S\oplus B, and A‚äïT‚äïBdirect-sumùê¥ùëáùêµA\oplus T\oplus B. Since (A,B)ùê¥ùêµ(A,B) is a socket, the cell must not contain BùêµB, A‚äïBdirect-sumùê¥ùêµA\oplus B, S‚äïTdirect-sumùëÜùëáS\oplus T, and S‚äïT‚äïBdirect-sumùëÜùëáùêµS\oplus T\oplus B. The cell may or may not contain the elements A‚äïTdirect-sumùê¥ùëáA\oplus T, B‚äïSdirect-sumùêµùëÜB\oplus S, and B‚äïTdirect-sumùêµùëáB\oplus T.

The indene molecule has a graph with a Kekul√© cell with these properties, as depicted here. The 9 interior nodes form a pentagon and a hexagon. In this case Pow‚Äã(P)ŒµPowsubscriptùëÉùúÄ\mbox{{Pow}}(P)_{\mbox{$\varepsilon$}} has dimension 5, and 32 elements. The Kekul√© cell has 18 elements. We use the input socket (A,B)ùê¥ùêµ(A,B) and the output channels SùëÜS, TùëáT as depicted. Incidentally, SùëÜS and TùëáT also form a socket. Initially, there are double bonds at both ports of channel Aùê¥A and at the eastern port of SùëÜS. Indene has several solutions of this type, but all of these have initially three double bonds at ports, have output channels combined in a socket, and have the elements A‚äïTdirect-sumùê¥ùëáA\oplus T, B‚äïSdirect-sumùêµùëÜB\oplus S, and B‚äïTdirect-sumùêµùëáB\oplus T in the Kekul√© cell.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we presented a theoretical investigation into the computational possibilities of polycyclic hydrocarbons, based on connectivity via molecular paths with alternating single and double bonds. We confirmed and extended the results presented in [17]. Moreover, we introduced the new concepts of cell and functional cell in order to characterize the switching behaviour of single unsaturated polycyclic hydrocarbon molecules. We regard this as an interesting and fascinating subject, both from the point of view of new chemistry and new applications of mathematics, as well as for the speculations about their potential for molecular computation. We showed that it is, in principle, possible to build logical switches with œÄùúã\pi-conjugated systems of unsaturated polycyclic hydrocarbons, but we are fully aware of the tremendous technical problems in realizing this potential. Anyway, the notion of functional cell emerging from our work is, in its own right, an interesting starting point for an alternative abstract model for computation. We showed that it encompasses logical switches; it would be interesting to investigate whether and how, e.g., data storage can be modeled with it.

So far, we have not yet found a connection between our investigations and quantum computing, although such a connection might very wel exist. The relevant properties of unsaturated polycyclic hydrocarbons are a direct consequence of the quantum mechanical behaviour of electrons, but there seems no role for entanglement here, which renders the connection with quantum computing still elusive.
